Dear Ms. Black-Moore:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and
your contract.

INVESTIGATION:
It should be noted that this Consultant attempted to contact the referral source on
several occasions by way of telephone calls and an email to discuss the
allegations. However, the telephone number was not a working telephone number
and the email address does not exit. It is noted that the referral source provided
inadequate information to be contacted therefore, additional and specific
information was not provided to properly investigate allegations 1-5. Allegations 1 –
5 were investigated by way of case records and a tour through the
agencies where case records are stored. The results were as follows:
Allegation 1. Facility fails to fulfill contract requirements. This statement is
very vague and there is no clear understanding of what the referral source
meant by this statement. More clarification was needed from the referral
source.
Allegation 2. Foster homes have not had yearly visits updated reports.
Allegation 3. Monthly foster home visits are missed.
I reviewed a random selection of four foster home case records. There were
no violations with these records regarding home visits. Foster home visits
were made, and it was noted that the Division Director visited some of the foster
homes to ensure compliance and to make sure the youth in these homes were
safe. This consultant conducted an Interim Inspection Report September of 2022.
There were no citations noted regarding foster home visits or annual/renewal
updated service plans. Documentation was noted in service plans and MiSACWIS.
Allegation 4. Transfers are completed without borrowed bed agreements
signed.
The agency had one borrowed bed. In review of this borrowed bed case
record, the agency had citations. The bed was borrowed, and it was cited in
the agency Interim Inspection Report dated September 8, 2022, that the case
record did not have documentation for the rule. The borrowed bed agreement was
not signed by the foster parent and the borrowing agency. See Interim Inspection
Report dated September 8, 2022. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective
action plan (CAP) and the CAP is still under review for this citation.
Allegation 5. Files are not organized and missing. This statement was
vague and needs additional information from the referral source who
611 W. OTTAWA • P.O. BOX 30664 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara • 517-335-1980

provided no reliable contact information. It was unclear of what files are
missing or unorganized.
Allegation 6. Special evaluations are not completed.
I interviewed the Division Director regarding the allegation made regarding special
investigations not being completed timely. The Division Director reported that this
information is true. She said there were three investigations that were initiated but
was not completed in a timely manner. The Division Director reported that the
agency experience significant staff turnover that was much greater than previous
years. She said the average tenure of staff is six months to one year. The Division
Director reported that she had to hire licensing staff because the staff and supervisor
all left the agency around the same time leaving unfinished special investigation
report unfinished.
I interviewed the Licensing Supervisor. She has been in the position since August of
2022 and newly hired. She explained that she is working diligently with her
supervisor to complete the special investigations that were initiated by another
licensing worker and supervisor who are no longer at the agency. She said there
were several special investigations that were not completed timely.
I interviewed the Director of Operations and she said she was aware of the special
investigations that were not completed timely. They were as follows:
Special investigation SI# 2021C0630170 was initiated on 08/19/21. The special
investigation was not completed as of 09/07/2022. The same investigation does not
have a conclusion based on the noncompliance and the findings of facts.
Special investigation SI#2022C0630986 was initiated on 05/06/2022. This special
investigation was not completed as of 09/07/2022. The report was missing Rule
12327 parts 3, 5f, 5h, 6a, 6b, 6c, and 7 of the rule.
Special investigation SI#2022C630008 was initiated on 09/10/2021 and was
completed on 08/17/2022. The report required a corrective action plan. There was
no corrective action plan for this special investigation.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional
time is required, then the agency shall inform the foster
parent, in writing, of the basis for the extension and the
expected length of the extension. The total time for the
completion of the investigation shall not exceed 90

www.michigan.gov/lara • 517-335-1980

calendar days without written approval from the chief
administrator or his or her designee.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(f) Conclusions regarding licensing rules compliance or
noncompliance based on the findings of fact.
(h) Recommendations regarding licensing action and any
required corrective action.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days
of its completion.
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing that he or she has a
right to have his or her written response included as an
attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services
worker that has children placed in the home.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social service workers who have
children placed in the home shall be notified there is a
corrective action plan and what is required of the foster
parent in that plan.
ANALYSIS: The referral source could not be contacted for this investigation
and provided inadequate contact information.
There were violations with the one case the agency had
regarding borrowed beds. There was a corrective action plan
submitted in September of 2022, this citation is in the interim
report and is still under review.
The Division Director, Director of Operations and Licensing
Supervisor all admitted that there were special investigation
reports that were not completed, and they were working on
completing the special investigations and will make them their
priority. The agency is in violation with not completing special
investigations timely.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
